Issues.Title: Select attribute "multiple" always generates an array as resulting model
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

### Description

By specification, the multiple attribute in a select should be boolean. 

The browsers seem to respect this attribute well, but in Angular I always get an array (model) as soon as the attribute is given, no matter what the value is.

This means that the use of `<select [multiple]="dynamicValue">...</select>` for single selects (with `dynamicValue = false`) is cumbersome because the resulting model is always an array.

Issues.Title: Expose declarations property in NgModuleRef
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

What we are trying to reach:
render component dynamically by importing the angular module file and pick the component type from the module declarations without the need to import the component directly. 

We are using dynamic rendering for components in our app. Now as compileModuleAndAllComponentsSync is deprecated there is no angular way get a component type from an angular module file, which is needed to create a component dynamically using createComponent. 

We are aware that we can directly import an angular component but this does not match our application architecture. Cause we are bundling the lazy module in each module in a file and with the direct import of a component we get a bundle component per file.

Now we have a work around to access the declarations property of an NgModule by accessing the emod property, but it is probably not the appropriate way to do that. 

As Angular offers different ways to render components, it would be great to consider this scenario and offer a way to dynamically import components from module file. 


### Proposed solution

Angular should expose the declarations property in the NgModuleRef which is already loaded into emod property 

### Alternatives considered

accessing the emod property on the imported module to allow access to the module componets types
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Expose declarations property in NgModuleRef   " (#47387)

Issues.Title: getBoundingClientRect() delay in ngAfterViewInit()
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

A similar issue (#17588) has been closed and can not add comment. 

When I tried to use **getBoundingClientRect()** like below in my Ionic(v6) project with Angular, it will get the wrong position.
```
ngAfterViewInit() {
  oneElement.getBoundingClientRect(); 
}

{
    "x": 0,
    "y": 0,
    "width": 0,
    "height": 0,
    "top": 0,
    "right": 0,
    "bottom": 0,
    "left": 0
}
```

Use **getBoundingClientRect()** in a **setTimeOut()** like below, and then it works correctly. But this is not a good idea due to unsure the internet condition in the client.
```
ngAfterViewInit() {
  setTimeOut(() => {
    oneElement.getBoundingClientRect(); 
  }, 150);     // it will return correct position, delay time varies for internet speed
}
```

I use the two elements one from `ion-page` content and the other from `<ion-tab-bar>`. I supposed it seems like due to render delay. At the time of calling **getBoundingClientRect()**, the DOM or the Page still changing.

I use this function for a dynamic tooltip with [floating-ui](https://floating-ui.com/) and a dynamic arrow with [arrows-svg](https://www.npmjs.com/package/arrows-svg). I tried Angular lifecycle and Ionic lifecycle but couldn't find a solution for dealing with attaching elements processes. Issues.Title: devServer proxy strips Access-Control-Allow-* headers
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.1

### Description

Since version 14.2, proxied OPTIONS requests are missing Access-Control-Allow-* headers from the origin (and seem to add/replace `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`).

Before, up to version 14.1, having a proxy configured like so:

```json
{
  "/api": {
    "target": "http://localhost:18080",
    "changeOrigin": true,
    "ws": true
  }
}
```

Worked fine when the browser was making an CORS preflight OPTIONS request.

Here's 3 requests, first directly to the origin, second using local dev-server with Angular CL v14.1 and third using v14.2.


Request to origin:

```shell
curl -v 'http://localhost:18080/api/log' \
  -X 'OPTIONS' \
  -H 'access-control-request-headers: content-type' \
  -H 'access-control-request-method: POST' \
  -H 'origin: http://localhost:4200'

< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2022 10:06:10 GMT
< Cache-Control: must-revalidate,no-cache,no-store
< Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://localhost:4200
< Vary: Origin
< Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
< Access-Control-Max-Age: 60
< Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET,POST,DELETE,PUT,HEAD,PATCH
< Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Accept,Accept-Language,Authorization,Content-Type,Origin,User-Agent,X-Requested-With
< Content-Type: text/plain
< Allow: POST,OPTIONS
< Content-Length: 13
```

Same request, but proxied by dev-server in v14.1:
```shell
curl -v 'http://localhost:18080/api/log' \
  -X 'OPTIONS' \
  -H 'access-control-request-headers: content-type' \
  -H 'access-control-request-method: POST' \
  -H 'origin: http://localhost:4200'

< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< X-Powered-By: Express
< access-control-allow-origin: http://localhost:4200
< connection: close
< date: Mon, 05 Sep 2022 10:38:12 GMT
< cache-control: must-revalidate,no-cache,no-store
< vary: Origin
< access-control-allow-credentials: true
< access-control-max-age: 60
< access-control-allow-methods: GET,POST,DELETE,PUT,HEAD,PATCH
< access-control-allow-headers: Accept,Accept-Language,Authorization,Content-Type,Origin,User-Agent,X-Requested-With
< content-type: text/plain
< allow: POST,OPTIONS
< content-length: 13
```

Same request, but proxied by dev-server in v14.2:
```shell
curl -v 'http://localhost:18080/api/log' \
  -X 'OPTIONS' \
  -H 'access-control-request-headers: content-type' \
  -H 'access-control-request-method: POST' \
  -H 'origin: http://localhost:4200'

< HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
< X-Powered-By: Express
< Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
< Content-Length: 0
< Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2022 10:49:26 GMT
< Connection: keep-alive
< Keep-Alive: timeout=5
```

Also, only noticing now after writing this, I see that the response status code is also changed/overriden.

### Minimal Reproduction

- Create a new app with `ng new ng-cli-cors-headers`, cd into its directory.
- Create a file `proxy.conf.json` with above contents (although using a different target that also responds to OPTIONS requests with specific Access-Control-Allow-* response headers)
- `ng serve --proxy-config proxy.conf.json`
- issue above mentioned curl requests and observe the missing headers

Issues.Body:
Previously, when there was an error during a build that had service workers enabled, the dev-server crashed as the promise was rejected instead of emitting a compilation error.

With this change we update the logic so that any errors during the SW augmentation phase are changed to a compilation error and also update the logic so that when there are compilation errors we don't try to generate a SW.

##### ⚠ BREAKING CHANGES

-   Drop Node.js 10.x support. This library always aims at supporting one EOLed LTS release which by this time now is 12.x which has reached EOL 30 Apr 2022.

-   Remove the minified UMD build from the package.

    Minified code is hard to audit and since this is a widely used library it seems more appropriate nowadays to optimize for auditability than to ship a legacy module format that, at best, serves educational purposes nowadays.

    For production browser use cases, users should be using a bundler. For educational purposes, today's online sandboxes like replit.com offer convenient ways to load npm modules, so the use case for UMD through repos like UNPKG or jsDelivr has largely vanished.

-   Drop IE 11 and Safari 10 support. Drop support for browsers that don't correctly implement const/let and default arguments, and no longer transpile the browser build to ES2015.

    Browser tests are run in the first supported version of each supported browser and in the latest (as of this commit) version available on Browserstack.

Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

As highlighted in https://github.com/angular/components/pull/18800, the page size dropdown looks wrong if a default formfield style is set globally.

Based on this page, the recommendation is to avoid using the "standard" or "legacy" setting for formfield appearance: https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview

It therefore seems to make sense to set a global default, but this breaks the page size dropdown.

My understanding is that overriding this is a case of adding a provider as follows:

```ts
        {
            provide: MAT_PAGINATOR_DEFAULT_OPTIONS,
            useValue: { formFieldAppearance: 'legacy' }
        }
```

Should this be documented?

```

</mat-menu>
<ng-template #menuTemplate>

```
In case of using ngTemplateOutlet in mat-menu (see code example above), the focus doesn't work as expected (see behavior sections).

- First menu item is focused when dropdown is opened.
- Up/down arrow keys can be used to navigate through the menu items.

(Expected behavior can be checked on the **Menu without ngTemplateOutlet** button too)

### Actual Behavior

- First menu item is not focused when dropdown is opened.
- Up/down arrow keys can't be used to navigate through the menu items.

Note: If the user keep pressing the tab, they can eventually focus the first menu item in the dropdown, but even then, the arrow keys won't work.

Issues.Title: feat(MatDIalog): Allow specifying MatDialogConfig as part of the dialog component
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Currently if there is a dialog which is meant to be used with a specific width, height, autoFocus, disableClose, etc... each and every code that opens that dialog need to specify those values. Even if extracted to a const you still need to remember to pass it.
 
What I wish to have is the ability to specify on the dialog component itself those configuration options or at least some of them that make sense. Allowing to actually "declare" to the one using - If you pass nothing in the `open` function config - this is the recommended and default config for this specific dialog. If you do pass a config object it overrides the recommended one.

### Use Case

When having a dialog that needs for example to have `autoFocus` as false always as it handles it inside - everyone using that dialog has to remember to declare this specific config when opening otherwise the dialog won't work as expected. Even if it was extracted to a const - the one opening the dialog still needs to know that const exists and remember to pass it.
The suggestion allows the dialog creator to specify the default config.

Issues.Title: bug(all): High Contrat Mode is broken?! after page refresh
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Enabling High Contrast after page load produces different styles than enabling it before (or after page refresh).
After page load the Button page of docs looks like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17689719/188420511-acd0d24d-2f57-4e4e-8a91-f2c5ef174725.png)
All buttons have outline and the currently focused element (Overview tab) has a nice strong focus indicator.

Hitting F5 and they are all gone
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17689719/188420914-d384b57f-8004-4a80-9730-bc2e74f8a06a.png)
The currently focused element has a bit more contrast but that's all.

Other components have malfunction too, like FormField

Before refresh:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17689719/188421940-4c6b5314-94f4-408a-a5d4-59d5a19954dd.png)
After refresh:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17689719/188421811-6c758a8f-6bdd-44b8-a7e1-3b8c136f30f8.png)

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://material.angular.io/components/button/overview
2. Enable High Contrast (shortcut: Alt key + left Shift key + Print screen)
3. Check the styles
4. Press F5


### Expected Behavior

I think they should look like the first time, and the styles after F5 are not accessible.

### Actual Behavior

They differ

### Environment

- Angular: 14.x
- CDK/Material: 14.x
- Browser(s): Microsoft Edge Version 105.0.1343.25 (Official build) (64-bit) / Google Chrome Version 105.0.5195.102 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): 
Edition	Windows 11 Pro
Version	21H2
OS build	22000.856
Experience	Windows Feature Experience Pack 1000.22000.856.0

### Note

This might be caused by the browser or Windows. `HighContrastModeDetector` can't detect it beacuse the coerced color for me is not `rgb(0,0,0)` but `rgb(32,32,32)`. I could not find the reason it works when I dynamically change the contrast, as the debugger won't stop at any of my breakpoints. However when I attach a breakpoint to the `body` itself (like right click on the node and break on attribute modifications) it breaks and works like on page refresh. It stops [HERE](https://github.dev/angular/components/blob/f379e803fd8c3e4298a244f3e438ec249f94cab5/src/cdk/a11y/high-contrast-mode/high-contrast-mode-detector.ts#L111) with the breakpoint on the element, but not when I mark it.

### Note 2

It is caused by Windows. In Windows 11 they have new high contrast themes.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17689719/188444113-86c69043-f577-4182-885c-ef593d718acb.png)
